Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i \omega t} \\) where \\( \omega \\) is a complex constant. We analyze the behavior of this system when subjected to a Fourier transform, defined as \\( \mathcal{F}(z)(\xi) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-i \xi t} z(t) \, dt \\).

If a damping factor \\( e^{-\alpha t} \\) (where \\( \alpha > 0 \\)) is applied to \\( z(t) = e^{i \omega t} \\) and then Fourier transformed, will the transform \\( \mathcal{F}(z)(\xi) \\) still primarily peak at \\( \xi = \omega \\)?
Explanation: The addition of a damping factor shifts the Fourier transform’s peak from \\( \omega \\) to a value depending on \\( \alpha \\). The influence of the exponential decay modifies the dominant frequency, thereby affecting the peak location in the transformed spectrum.
